docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is nothing like a will to give billionaire watchers something to gab about. And one morsel in Harry B. Helmsley's estate should keep them buzzing for quite a while. The New York real-estate mogul, who by most accounts was golden-hearted compared with his wife, Leona, left Ceil Fried, his longtime secretary, $25,000, a minuscule part of his $1.7 billion estate. That is all that decades of dictation, menial tasks and juggling one of the world's busiest social schedules was worth to Helmsley.

headline.main: In Serving the Famous, Is a Ringside Seat Enough?

docs.abstract: Recent cases in which wealthy, powerful people left little or nothing to longtime employees have surprised estate lawyers and raised ire of many of nation's 2.6 million executive assistants, personal secretaries and other servants of rich and powerful; former aides to some of nation's top celebrities, most of whom are now dead, report mostly fond memories of catering to whims and coping with mood swings of former masters, interviews; table; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As they plan their budgets for the next fiscal year, New Jersey's municipalities will be getting a discount on health benefits for their public employees.
docs.abstract: New Jersey's municipalities will get discount on health insurance for their public employees, as Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey has cut its fees, in part because of reduced administrative costs (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)
docs.snippet: As they plan their budgets for the next fiscal year, New Jersey's municipalities will be getting a discount on health benefits for their public employees.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: BLUE CROSS & BLUE SHIELD OF NEW JERSEY

docs.lead_paragraph: I am a resident physician. My job is exciting and challenging. But it could be much improved with one simple change: Take me off the Government dole. Through Medicare, hospitals receive about $100,000 each year for every resident they employ -- about $7 billion nationwide. As a resident, this subsidy pays my salary and defrays the costs of my training. But it also has bizarre effects that undermine my education, my ability to eventually find a good job, even my quality of life.
docs.abstract: Op-ed column by Lloyd M Krieger, resident physician at UCLA Medical Center, scores present system of financing training of medical residents, contending that it is resulting in surplus of residents, and will make it harder for young doctors to find work (M)
